headline.print_headline: As Turmoil Subsides, Tourism in Nepal Surges
headline.main: As Turmoil Subsides, Tourism in Nepal Surges

docs.lead_paragraph: For those who have deferred journeys to Katmandu, the good news is that the troubled decade did nothing to harm the city’s age-old appeal.

headline.main: A Borough Used to Brickbats Is Hurled Some Modest Bouquets

docs.abstract: Article on recent focus on positive aspects of Bronx, NY, in weekly magazine Time Out New York and Bronx Tourism Council's free guide, Where to Eat in the Bronx; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: After Yankee Stadium and the zoo, the Bronx has been best known during the last quarter century for its ravaged buildings, persistent drug problem and soaring crime rates, making it the borough most likely to be avoided. But seemingly overnight, the Bronx seems to have become a destination.

headline.main: U.S. VACATIONS AS MODEL; European Parley Seeks Ways to Broaden Tourism Base

docs.lead_paragraph: MILAN, Italy Man's need to pack up his family and head off on regular vacations was given strong endorsement here last week at the third International Congress of Social Tourism. Attention was focused on means for putting holiday travel within the reach of everyone.

docs.abstract: Meeting of World Tourism Congress, Manila, is disrupted when US delegation threatens to walk out with Israelis in dispute over Jerusalem; Arab nations led by Syria successfully blocked accreditation of 2 Israeli delegates, Gen Yoram Ziv--director of tourism--and diplomat Moshe Ram, because their papers had been issued in Jerusalem rather than Tel Aviv (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: MANILA, Oct. 9--A controversy over Jerusalem disrupted a meeting here today of the World Tourism Congress as the United States delegation threatened to walk out with the Israelis.

byline.original: Special to The New York Times

headline.print_headline: Hundreds Missing After Chinese Cruise Ship Sinks on Yangtze
headline.main: Hundreds Missing After Chinese Cruise Ship Sinks on Yangtze

docs.abstract: China's news agency says chartered cruise ship sank in storm on Yangtze River, with most of 458 people aboard still missing; reports only 13 people have been rescued.
docs.lead_paragraph: China’s official news agency said the ship sank Monday night in a storm, and as of Tuesday morning, local media reported the rescue of only a small number of people.

byline.contributor: Michael Forsythe contributed reporting from Hong Kong, and Kiki Zhao, Mia Li and Adam Wu contributed research from Beijing.

docs.lead_paragraph: READING AND CRUNCHING ALTHOUGH libraries are supposed to be the quietest of places, in the West Babylon Public Library you kind of expect to hear the crunch from someone munching on a potato chip or two. After all, it's not only books that are stored in the 24,000-square-foot building on Route 109. According to the library director, William D. Cicola, Frito-Lay Inc. leases 10,000 square feet in the back of the building as its warehouse and distribution center for western Suffolk County and eastern Nassau County. ''We're known as the Frito-Lay library,'' Mr. Cicola said. Sometimes the Frito-Lay trucks seem to outnumber the library patrons' cars in the parking lot, but leasing space has been advantageous to the library district. The monthly rent helps pay the mortgage, Mr. Cicola said. ''I think we're unique,'' he added. ''Most libraries start out by renting store space. Before they buy a building they're the tenants. We're the reverse - in the West Babylon library, we have the tenants.''

headline.print_headline: Debt-Heavy Portugal Reaps Windfall From Surge in Tourism
headline.main: Debt-Heavy Portugal Reaps Windfall From Surge in Tourism

docs.lead_paragraph: Portugal's fragile economy is getting a tonic from tourism this year, with revenue up by more than 10 percent through October including a 20 percent jump in visitors from the United States.
docs.snippet: Portugal's fragile economy is getting a tonic from tourism this year, with revenue up by more than 10 percent through October including a 20 percent jump in visitors from the United States....

headline.main: Business Travel; An experiment by United Airlines to further limit carry-on baggage is well received by passengers.

docs.abstract: United Airlines' one-bag carry-on policy experiment that began two weeks ago is well received by passengers; Continental Airlines opened its third Presidents Club at Newark International Airport on Dec 15; study by Tourism Works for America Council shows that 46.3 million international travelers to US in 1996 spent $90.5 billion, while 52.3 million Americans who traveled to international destinations spent $64.5 billion, or $26 billion less; Amtrak is well along toward installing 150 self-service ticketing kiosks in 43 rail stations nationwide (Business Travel) (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: TWO weeks ago, UAL's United Airlines began a one-bag carry-on policy experiment for passengers in Des Moines who buy the lowest-fare tickets, and other carriers also tightened their carry-on policies. Since then, airlines say, there appears to be both more rigorous enforcement of the policies and wider compliance with them. But the true test, they add, will be determined when planes are no longer routinely jammed with passengers, and carriers and passengers alike relax their guard. While the Federal Aviation Administration has already said it does not favor regulation, business travelers are chiming in with suggestions for improvement. A recent survey of members by the National Business Travel Association found that 63 percent of respondents want carry-on luggage restrictions applied to all passengers regardless of ticket class or air fare. A survey by Yesawich, Pepperdine & Brown/Yankelovich Partners did not address the number of carry-on bags, but found that 65 percent of business travelers want more space for the baggage they do carry on.

headline.main: IN PARIS, A TASTE FOR 'TEX-MEX' AND 'CHIENS CHAUDS'

docs.lead_paragraph: The honor just paid to an American restaurant in Paris reflects the growing popularity in France of American food and the proliferation of American-style restaurants here. Throughout Paris, young French people are lining up for ''les hamburgers,'' ''les chiens chauds'' (hot dogs) and a wide variety of other American dishes. This fascination with American cuisine was reflected in a rare tribute earlier this week. The International Action Committee for Gastronomy and Tourism awarded its annual prize - the Plat Vermeil or Gold-Plated Dish - for the best foreign food in Paris to Papa Maya, a new Texas-Mexican restaurant near Les Halles, the former central marketplace of the city.

byline.original: By JUDITH MILLER, Special to the New York Times

keywords.value: ACTION COMMITTEE FOR GASTRONOMY AND TOURISM, INTERNATIONAL
keywords.name: organizations
